meanings.def: to make something/somebody clean using water and usually soap
examples: wash something/somebody These jeans need washing.
He always washes the car on Sundays.
to wash your hands/hair/face
Wash the fruit thoroughly before eating.
wash something from something She washed the blood from his face.
wash something/somebody + adj. The potatoes are washed clean without damaging the skins.
The villa is cleaned twice a week.
Have you cleaned your teeth?
This coat is filthy. I’ll have it cleaned (= dry-cleaned).
He quickly washed his hands and face.
These jeans need washing.
Make sure you rinse all the soap out.
Hands need to be washed regularly with hot water.
She gently washed and dressed the wound.
the smell of freshly washed hair
He quickly washed his hands and face.
He washed his face.
If you wash the dishes, I'll dry.

meanings.def: to make yourself clean using water and usually soap
examples: By this time we were already washed and dressed.
I washed and changed before going out.
Mick woke up, got washed and shaved, and put his work clothes on.
wash yourself She was no longer able to wash herself.

meanings.def: to be able to be washed without losing colour or being damaged
examples: This sweater washes well.

meanings.def: to flow or carry something/somebody in a particular direction
examples: + adv./prep. Water washed over the deck.
wash something/somebody + adv./prep. Pieces of the wreckage were washed ashore.
He was washed overboard by a huge wave.
wash something + adj. The beach had been washed clean by the tide.

meanings.def: to discuss your personal affairs in public, especially something embarrassing
to refuse to be responsible for or involved with somebody/something
examples: When her son was arrested again she washed her hands of him.
I’ve washed my hands of the whole sordid business.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody’s explanation, excuse, etc. is not true or that you/somebody else will not accept it
examples: That excuse simply won't wash with me.

idioms.idiom: air/wash your dirty laundry/linen in public
idioms.def: to discuss your personal affairs in public, especially something embarrassing
to refuse to be responsible for or involved with somebody/something
examples: When her son was arrested again she washed her hands of him.
I’ve washed my hands of the whole sordid business.

idioms.def: used to say that somebody’s explanation, excuse, etc. is not true or that you/somebody else will not accept it
examples: That excuse simply won't wash with me.

meanings.def: an act of cleaning somebody/something using water and usually soap
examples: These towels are ready for a wash.
I'll just have a quick wash before dinner.
The curtains could do with a good (= thorough) wash.
I'm doing a dark wash (= washing all the dark clothes together).
Your shirt's in the wash (= being washed or waiting to be washed).
My sweater shrank in the wash.
That blouse shouldn't look like that after only two washes.

meanings.def: an area of water that has waves and is moving a lot, especially after a boat has moved through it; the sound made by this
examples: The dinghy was rocked by the wash of a passing ferry.
They listened to the wash of waves on the beach.
Seagulls hovered above the wash of the trawler.

meanings.def: a thin layer of a liquid, especially paint, that is put on a surface
examples: The walls were covered with a pale yellow wash.

meanings.def: a liquid containing soap, used for cleaning your skin
examples: an antiseptic skin wash

meanings.def: used to say that the truth about a situation will be made known at some time in the future
examples: This will all come out in the wash.

meanings.def: used to make somebody less anxious by telling them that any problems or difficulties will be solved in the future

idioms.idiom: it will (all) come out in the wash
idioms.def: used to say that the truth about a situation will be made known at some time in the future
examples: This will all come out in the wash.
